message.body: Hey, what's up
not much, how are you doing?
Ha! Pretty good.
Bought a flash drive. 8 gigs for like $7.
A few years ago an 8 gig flash drive would have been mindblowing, now it's nothing
nice, that's super cheap
I've been thinking about getting a new thumb drive
I've got a few portable external drives, but having a nice small one would be pretty convenient.
Did you see the coverage for the Xbox One?
I'm not big into gaming but I'm always interested to see the new systems
I haven't. Unfortunately I don't pay attention to either the news or new systems coming out.
The last game I actually played was NHL 97 for Genesis
What's the skinny on the new Xbox?
I just saw some people upset about the games being married to the system
so once you install a game on a machine, you can't play that game on any other xbox...
ah, weak
In general I'm against the trend towards restrictions of that sort
mostly I encounter it with music
I was thinking about it a few weeks ago - I haven't bought a cd in forever
it's so odd
Yeah, neither have I
it's also gotten to the point where I feel like actually paying money for music has become almost a political thing
like I have friends who will get free music, but pay for music from a band who's lesser known
yep
i do the same
If it's some unknown artist and I'm listening to a song or two nonstop and they have an easy purchase option (bandcamp), I'll buy it
yeah, but if it's Metallica...
jl
jk, rather
I forgot about all that crazy
yeah, I'm not a fan of the band, but I am a HUGE fan of the documentary about them, Some Kind of Monster
so good
yeah, how have I forgotten to see that
I actually had a really difficult time trying to find it on DVD.
Searched Blockbuster, Borders, Barnes and Noble and finally found it at some point used at FYE
but it's become one of my faves over the years
Blockbuster, egads
scary how blockbuster and borders are gone
wonder how long b&n will last
there are still a few blockbusters out there
Remember tower records?
Yeah, i've seen that - I just can't believe it though.
I always figured if I tried to go see a still-existing blockbuster, it would be like trying to find a ghost town. A mirage.
You get to where it's supposed to be, and there is just an old white-mustached prospector with a gravelly voice askin how you heard about "The Block Buster"
I visit family in South Carolina for the holidays and they've still got one
we almost always go there cuz there's nothing else to do
but it seems like in most major city areas they're dead dead dead
Where are you currently
the Philly area
how bout you?
same
nice, how long have you been living here?
just a few years
you?
I'm just about to hit my ten-year mark
how do you find it?
I was in florida before this, and it is definitely a big change.
there is a lot of history here, so that makes up for the appearance of places
but it's the reverse there
yeah, everything was developed probably in like the 50s-70s there? does that seem about right? or earlier?
probably, yeah. It just seems like a city of gold, of streaming light and magic.
And so by contrast, philly is like finding an old shack in the woods that Ben Franklin once used
humble but functional
yeah, I'm a big fan of Philly
it's got a great creative pulse, it's cheap, but it's also really urban
not in a run-down way so much, though, like Detroit or St. Louis
Oh god yeah - Detroit seems like a pre-postapocalyptic wasteland, and St. Louis just seems like a garbage dump that people are forced to live in.
Keep in mind I've never been to either place and I'm sure the people there are just lovely, but...
no, that's pretty accurate; I've been to both places a few times in the last few years
although I did hear that Detroit is starting to hit a new revitalization, now that I come to think about it
I think that younger people, artists, hipsters and the like, are starting to forge a path of gentrification that's increasing the population
